comments:
I wrote my own OSGi adaptor. When I instrument it to see what entries are 
requested by the platform, I see differences between M6 and a recent I build.
On M6 only twelve requests were placed for Manifest files.
To get the manifest file, the jar has to be opened, of course.
I measured both existence checks and actually reading the contents.
18 plugins are loaded in my workspace. For 26 plugins, the Manifest's 
existence is verified (which is 8 too many, in my book), which forces the 
adaptor to open the jar. For none of them, the actual contents is read on M6.

On I20050411 I saw 50 requests to get the actual _contents_ for Manifest files:

I suspect this is because of the fix for bug 50133.  We parse all code jar 
manifests for package information to get the proper information for 
Class#getPackage method.  Now most bundles in Eclipse are being jar'ed 
with '.' on the Bundle-ClassPath.  This means the bundle jar is now a code jar 
with a manifest file that is parsed to get the package information at class 
load time.

when is the manifest parsed?  Seems like there are 50 being parsed.  I would 
not expect 50 classloaders to be created.

Sidenote:  Can we cache a bit that says whether or not the manifest has any 
package info?  Most do not so it seems a waste to parse.  Presumably we know at 
bundle install time if there is any package info in the manifest.  We can mark 
up the BundleData to say.  This way we can avoid reading the manifests.

Chris, when you see 50 manifests being read is during a fresh start (clean 
configuration area) or launching from a cached config?

I did a similar exercise and found similar numbers on initial startup, but 
when starting from a cached config I only saw the manifests being parsed for 
the jar files used to load classes from.

Jeff, we can look into marking bundledata objects if no package info is found 
in the bundle manifest.

I just ran -clean, and then 3 more runs, just to make sure. I am seeing lots 
of getEntry calls for plugin.xml, properties, and Manifests. Here are the last 
of each three:

I have done quite a bit of testing on I20050419. I tested by instrumenting the
OSGi JAR directly, and running a normal eclipse with that instrumented jar (not
self-hosting, not a runtime workbench).  My results are very close to what Tom
observed in comment #4.

My first test was an "empty" workspace in the resource perspective.  Results are
from the second run with a cached configuration (no -clean, etc).

Plugins started: 19
Requests for contents of MANIFEST.MF files: 21
Manifests parsed in EclipseClasspathEntry (see comment #7): 20

Another test with a bigger workspace, Java perspective open, editors open:

Plugins started: 33
Requests for contents of MANIFEST.MF files: 40
Manifests parsed in EclipseClasspathEntry (see comment #7): 37

So, almost all occurrences of parsing manifests occur as a side-effect of
classloading in an activated plugin.

Question 1: Why does Chris get different results?  Perhaps his adapter is
causing more plugins to be loaded or more manifests to be parsed that otherwise
would not. Perhaps we have improved since 20050411 when he did these measurements.

Question 2: Can we do better?  Tom, you suggest in comment #4 that we could
avoid this manifest parsing in the classloader through better caching.  Have you
looked into that?

IBuild20050426. The short summary is:

M6:	16 plugins activated, 69 available plugins 
	24 classloaders created, 18 Manifests read
0426:	18 plugins activated, 66 available plugins
	68 classloaders created, 85 Manifests read

I wonder what I do wrong to cause so much more loading...
Anybody know what changed between M6 and now?

Re comment 10 Question 2:

We can do better for jar'ed bundles.  At install time we can perform an extra 
check of the manifest file to see if the bundle manifest file has extra 
package information in it.  If it does not then we can add some information to 
the bundledata to indicate that the bundle manifest file should not be parsed 
for package information at classload time.

For non-jar'ed bundles we can do some extra work to see if the jars on the 
bundle classpath have manifests with extra package information,  If they do 
not then we can add some information for each of the classpath entries to 
indicate that the manifests should not be parsed.

I found the problem. I ran my eclipse+adaptor from Eclipse, and had the wrong 
working directory selected. The runtime tried to find all the plugins there, 
and found none, opening all jars to get the Manifest files as a result. 
After fixing the working directory, I get these numbers:

Eclipse startup statistics
Time and I/O:

Note that half of the class/resource loading is for non-existing elements.
